message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: On State-Constrained Containment Control for Nonlinear Multiagent Systems Using Event-Triggered Input
Paper Abstract: The neural-approximation-based adaptive nonlinear containment control issue for multiagent systems with full-state constraints is studied by invoking the backstepping approach. First, the barrier Lyapunov functions are established to deal with the state constraining issue in the multiple leaders/followers control scenarios. Then, by introducing the first-order filter, the system communication burden is substantially reduced. Moreover, the event-triggered controller is constructed by utilizing the switching-based mechanism so that the system security, control accuracy, resource consumption, and imposed state constraints are neatly balanced. We prove the output of each follower can converge to the desired hull formulated by leaders under the premise that the imposed state constraints are never violated. Besides, the considered closed-loop signals are uniformly bounded. We finally present a simulation example to show the validity of the developed approach.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, I found a reference to event-triggered control in the context of academic research. Here's what I found:

Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, was named Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

The search results primarily contained information about time-triggered systems and event-driven programming in software, but limited specific details about event-triggered control as a technical field. Event-triggered control is a specialized area within control theory and systems engineering that focuses on controlling systems based on specific events rather than continuous time-based updates. This contrasts with traditional control approaches that operate on fixed time intervals.

If you'd like more detailed technical information about event-triggered control theory and its applications, I could perform an additional search with more specific technical terms.

I've completed a web search on "Neural network approximation." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Universal Approximation

One of the most important theoretical concepts in neural network approximation is the universal approximation theorem. If the layer's activation function is non-polynomial (which is true for common choices like the sigmoid function or ReLU), then the network can act as a "universal approximator." 

There are two main approaches to achieving this universal approximation property:

- Universality is achieved by increasing the number of neurons in the hidden layer, making the network "wider."
- Other versions of the theorem show that universality can also be achieved by keeping the network's width fixed but increasing its number of layers, making it "deeper."

However, these are existence theorems that guarantee that a network with the right structure exists, but they do not provide a method for finding the network's parameters (training it), nor do they specify exactly how large the network must be for a given function.

## Applications

Applications of neural networks include function approximation, or regression analysis, (including time series prediction, fitness approximation, and modeling) as well as nonlinear system identification and control.

## Related Approaches

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov function stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"},{"title":"Chetaev instability theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chetaev_instability_theorem"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov functions and stability:

## Overview

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Key Concepts

Stability can be proven without requiring knowledge of the true physical energy, provided a Lyapunov function can be found to satisfy the above constraints.(no content)Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance) remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Conditions for Stability

If the equilibrium point is isolated, the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally positive definite, and the time derivative of the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally negative definite, then the equilibrium is proven to be locally asymptotically stable.

## Application to Optimization

System stability is achieved by taking control actions that make the Lyapunov function drift in the negative direction towards zero.

## Historical Context

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University (now VN Karazin Kharkiv National University) in 1892.

Web search results for query: "Backstepping control method"

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Back mount - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_mount"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Backpressure routing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpressure_routing"}]

Here are the search results for "Backstepping control method":

## Overview

The backstepping approach provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.(no content)The process "steps backward" from x out of the strict-feedback form system until the ultimate control u is designed.

## Key Characteristics

Any system in this special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated (e.g., as part of an adaptive control algorithm).(no content)Backstepping is one of the nonlinear control methods that takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## Historical Contribution

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Here are the search results for "Backstepping control method":

## Overview

The backstepping approach provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized, and the stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.(no content)The process "steps backward" from x out of the strict-feedback form system until the ultimate control u is designed.

## Key Characteristics

Any system in this special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated (e.g., as part of an adaptive control algorithm).(no content)Backstepping is one of the nonlinear control methods that takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

## Historical Contribution

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Katia Sycara - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katia_Sycara"},{"title":"Peter Stone (professor) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Stone_(professor)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Wassim Michael Haddad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wassim_Michael_Haddad"}]

## Search Results: Multiagent Systems

Here's a comprehensive overview of multiagent systems based on the search results:

### Definition and Overview
A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics
Agents in a multi-agent system have several important features:
- Autonomy: agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous; Local views: no agent has a full global view; and Decentralization: no agent is designated as controlling(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Related Fields
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Multiagent planning is concerned with planning by (and for) multiple agents, which can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

### Research Community
The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of adaptive control systems:

## Definition and Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Characteristics

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundational Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types and Approaches

Several broad categories of feedback adaptive control include dual adaptive controllers based on dual control theory and model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) which incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance.

## Applications and History

Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field. Real-world applications of adaptive control systems include adaptive cruise control in vehicles, traffic signal control systems, and robotics.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Chen Guanrong - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Guanrong"}]

## Nonlinear Control Theory

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)Control theory is an interdisciplinary branch of engineering and mathematics that is concerned with the behavior of dynamical systems with inputs, and how to modify the output by changes in the input using feedback, feedforward, or signal filtering.

### Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.

### Analysis and Design Techniques

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

### Practical Applications

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.(no content)Processes in industries like robotics and the aerospace industry typically have strong nonlinear dynamics.

### Modern Control Methods

Control techniques for nonlinear systems, such as feedback linearization, backstepping, sliding mode control, and trajectory linearization control normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

### Modern Control Methods

Control techniques for nonlinear systems, such as feedback linearization, backstepping, sliding mode control, and trajectory linearization control normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

Links: [{"title":"Low-pass filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-pass_filter"},{"title":"Butterworth filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butterworth_filter"},{"title":"High-pass filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-pass_filter"},{"title":"Digital filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_filter"},{"title":"Filter design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_design"},{"title":"Filter (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Infinite impulse response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_impulse_response"},{"title":"Finite impulse response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_impulse_response"},{"title":"First-order hold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_hold"},{"title":"Digital biquad filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_biquad_filter"}]

Here are the search results for "First-order filter signal processing":

## Overview

A filter in signal processing is a device or process that removes some unwanted components or features from a signal, with the defining feature of filters being the complete or partial suppression of some aspect of the signal.

## Characteristics of First-Order Filters

A first-order filter reduces the signal amplitude by half (so power reduces by a factor of 4, or 6 dB), every time the frequency doubles (goes up one octave). More precisely, a first-order filter's response rolls off at −6 dB per octave (−20 dB per decade).

## Types of First-Order Filters

**First-Order Low-Pass Filters:**
A first-order RL circuit is composed of one resistor and one inductor and is the simplest type of RL circuit, and is one of the simplest analogue infinite impulse response electronic filters.

**First-Order High-Pass Filters:**
First-order high-pass filters are called differentiators, because they perform differentiation for signals whose frequency band is well below the filter's cutoff frequency.

## Filter Order and Roll-Off

The order of a filter is the degree of the approximating polynomial and in passive filters corresponds to the number of elements required to build it. Increasing order increases roll-off and brings the filter closer to the ideal response.

## Applications

Filters are widely used in electronics and telecommunication, in radio, television, audio recording, radar, control systems, music synthesis, image processing, computer graphics, and structural dynamics.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! The analysis is complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution

The paper "On State-Constrained Containment Control for Nonlinear Multiagent Systems Using Event-Triggered Input" proposes novel methods for controlling multiagent systems with state constraints.

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Identified:**

1. **Backstepping** - Core control methodology for designing the containment control approach
2. **Lyapunov function** - Foundation for stability analysis, extended with barrier functions for state constraints
3. **Nonlinear control** - Framework for handling nonlinear multiagent systems
4. **Multi-agent system** - Primary problem domain with multiple leaders and followers
5. **Adaptive control** - Neural-approximation-based approach for handling uncertain parameters
6. **Universal approximation theorem** - Theoretical basis for neural network function approximation
7. **Filter (signal processing)** - First-order filters reduce communication burden
8. **Event-driven architecture** - Event-triggered control mechanism balances security, accuracy, and resource consumption
9. **Barrier method** - Novel barrier Lyapunov functions (proposed) enforce state constraints

All triples have been validated and the `triples_output.json` file is complete with proper Wikipedia references, entity types, and relevance descriptions.

Sources:
- [Backstepping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping)
- [Lyapunov function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function)
- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Universal approximation theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_approximation_theorem)
- [Filter (signal processing)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_(signal_processing))
- [Event-driven architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture)
- [Barrier function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_function)
